title: Retaining access to POP3 emails
content:
I have used Thunderbird with a POP3 account for years - it has become a large, handy, easily searched database of important information. MY ISP has forced me into Microsoft Office which doesn't support Thunderbird and, annoyed, I've jumped to Proton, which will allow me to continue with Thunderbird and to download my emails. My question is this:

Now that my old email address is no longer supported, Thunderbird goes nuts throwing up a constant message about not being able to connect. How do I stop this without deleting the actual account? (because if I do, I delete the entire database of emails associated with the account.). I just want to disable it so that it doesn't try to connect. And then I will simply add in my Proton email and carry on from there. At the moment, I get the message: "Log in to account "..." failed." and then three buttons - Enter new password, Cancel, Retry - but it doesn't stay concelled. It just keeps nagging me. And if I go into account settings, it won't let me disable the SMTP.

title: Single click being treated like double click in Thunderbird 102.11.0 (64-bit) as well as Zotero
content:
Since I updated to Thunderbird 102.11.0 (64-bit) on Ubuntu 20.04, I have this persistent problem that single clicks in the list of messages are often, but not always, treated as if they were double clicks, opening the messages in a separate tab. This makes it very hard to use Thunderbird as the focus is constantly changing from the list of messages to another unwanted tab. I have also started seeing this problem in Zotero, which uses the same underlying interface as Thunderbird, so I believe it is a general problem impacting all applications that use that (XUL?) interface. This is not a mouse problem as I have seen this on two different computers using two different mice, one of which is connected to the computer via a cable. I also have not noticed this problem in any of the other applications I use, so it is limited to Mozilla apps (but I have not seen this in Firefox for whatever reason - I believe firefox no longer uses XUL, right?).

Thanks, David
